Abandoned

There's no longer a need for this.
Hi, can you add doxygen comments to all of the new classes, like how the existing ones did it?  I think that will help make it easier to understand what's going on in this giant change set.
Sure, working on it.
Done.
There's a docs/sensor-monitor/README.md file that would be nice if you updated.  And maybe include an example recovery JSON file so we can get a feeling for what it looks like.
Hi Matt, first, thanks for all the advice you gave.
Sure, I've uploaded the example json file, the README will be added soon
nit: not needed
Done

I always forget about it, but sdbusplus.hpp has a static getBus() method that can return the sdbusplus::bus object, and it provides getProperties interfaces that don't take that parameter.

It would save having to store the references to it and pass it around.
Up to you though since the original code didn't do it.

Sure! I am so earger to find some mechanism to avoid passing around the sdbusplus::bus object, it will be great to use the method you mentioned to obtain the object.

Unfortonatly I haven't found the method yet, I'll update it once I figure it out.

It's this: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-fan-presence/blob/cb356d48f0ab00c4f5f774c68760d2c2afd14cd8/sdbusplus.hpp#L115

that you can use like:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-fan-presence/blob/cb356d48f0ab00c4f5f774c68760d2c2afd14cd8/presence/tach.cpp#L61

Done, thanks for the hints.
I've removed the references of sdbusplus::dbus and sdeventplus::event in DbusAlarmMonitor, AlarmChecker, and AlarmHandlers, and use the static methods to obtain the objects.
can't this just be a part of the class?

The variable is assigned at the checkAlarm() function, and be used when the timer expired.

In my experiment, I made the variable into a property of the class, the function call of Timer expired (i.e., triggerRecovery) could not get the corresponding instance, the string value will be empty.

It might be the life cycle issue, e.g., the object is deleted right after binding the timer call back function, but I haven't found a better solution for this yet, if you have any idea, please let me know, thanks!
Hmmm, not sure I follow. Which object is deleted before the timer expires?

I mean the instance of RecoveryAlarmHandlerwhich assigned the string "target" might be deleted right after the function RecoveryAlarmHandler::startTimer is successfully executed.

As a result, when the Timer expired, the timer will create another instance of RecoveryAlarmHandler and execute the function ProtectionAlarmHandler::triggerProtection, whose the string "target" is empty.
Looks like you removed the code from ShutdownAlarmMonitor::StartTimer() that checks for any persisted timestamps that means the BMC rebooted while the shutdown timer was running.

Yes, I've traced the code of checking the persisted timestamps, there are two scenarios that could trigger the persisted timestamps detection:
1. A timestamp didn't been deleted since any asynchronous error, e.g., property changed rapidly.
2. BMC reboot during the timer is running, BMC load the config and find there is a persisted timestamps (just like you mentioned).


For 1., I've conducted a stress test, which toggling the alarm rapidly and see if there is any timestamp not been deleted, since the timestamps are stored in the momory for sensor-monitor, and the corresponding timestamp should be deleted when stopTimer() and expired() are called. The result is pass.

For 2., the code in alarm_timestamps shows that after conduct any manipulation like add(), erase(), the json file "shutdownAlarmStartTimes" should be updated, I further checked the json file, it turns out that the file has no record for the timestamps, there was no error message to hint.

I do missed 2., thought there is no possible a persisted timestamps exist, I can add it back if my conslusion above is not wrong.

That is only there so that if there is a countdown running and the BMC gets rebooted, when sensor monitor comes back online it will pick up the countdown where it left off if there is still a threshold hit, otherwise reboots may prevent the system from shutting down in time.

While that is unlikely to occur, it is one of our requirements.
Sure, I've added it back (Can refer to startTimer() in ProtectionAlarmHandler).
not necessary
Done
If you return here, where does that leave the state machine?  I think i would still at least like to get a bmc dump.
Sure, I'll move the call of createBmcDump() before the dbus method call.
I think would prefer this to be where it was previously, which is before the hard power off call on line 218

Here are my thoughts, the createEventLog() sends SoftShutdown/HardShutdown event, which means a SoftShutdown/HardShutdown is triggered, if there is any exception is catched when executing the service, we might consider that the SoftShutdown/HardShutdown did not executed properly, so the event should not be sent.
can use 'contains()' in c++20
Done, thanks for the tips.
Why are you stopping the timer if the alarm is still triggered?

Timer expired in RecoveryAlarmHandler means the sensor is back to normal, the system will be recovered, if the alarm is asserted again during the timer activation, it means the sensor is unstable, the timer then stop until the alarm is de-asserted again.
This is the writeable /var/lib path.  I think instead you'll want it to go into /usr/share somewhere which is read only.
Done
nit: doesn't
Done
can use contains() here too
Done
nit: recovered
Done
may as well put the alarmType in here too
Done
const std::string& would be better.
Done
nit: extra blank line
Done

Not sure I follow what this function is doing.

Why are new recovery matches being added after the system is already shut down? Isn't that too late for recovery?  I thought recovery was just for the warning and critical thresholds.

And won't the warning and critical matches already exist from the DBusAlarmMonitor constructor?

Recovery means recover the system (i.e., restore the power state) after the sensor is back to normal state.

When sensor's HardShutdown/SoftShutdown alarm is triggered, it causes the host powered off, we call it system protection, when RecoverySubscriber capture a system protection event, it will check if the sensor needs to perform recovery detection by searching the recovery-action.json, and start watching the alarm defined in the config, the system won't be recovered until the alarm is de-assert, (i.e., the sensor is back to normal).

For example, the actual workflow in Greatlakes is:
1. NIC over temperature, OTP is triggered, 12V off.
2. sensor-monitor start watching the "CriticalAlarmHigh" alarm (Can refer to the sample json file) of the NIC's temperature sensor.
3. The temperature has dropped under CriticalAlarmHigh's threshold for more than 5 seconds (i.e., "StableCountdown in the config").
4. Recover the system, 12V on.

The DBusAlarmMonitor's constructor watches HardShutdown/SoftShutdown of all the sensors, which was originally implemented in ShutdownAlarmMonitor, I've moved it into DBusAlarmMonitor to comply with SRP (SOLID).
And here, why stop watching the alarm, because what if it trips again?
After the system has been recovered, which means the sensor is back to normal, then we shall not continually watching the alarm.
I'd suggest leave it as one long string and just take whatever clang-format does with it.  I've never see it add a backslash before to split it.
Done
this field isn't use by this class.
Done. Removed stableCountdown and changed the type of container from map<string, int> into vector<string>
It would be nice to share the code that loads the file with the other class that uses it.
Sure, I already have an idea for refactoring the config loading mechanism, I'll push another commit to improve the reusability!
usually const std::string&
Done
shouldn't these classes either override getName() or store the name in the class and return that?

Oh, this is an unused function, it was a workaround of inheritance mechanism of C++, there must be at least one virtual function to let children classes override the parent class, I has fulfilled the requirement by claiming a virtual destrutor, I'll delete the getName() function.

noticed this while testing.  could probably just change it to a debug trace.

Or, do it after the get property call and print the sensor value.

I think the ERR level log in the catch block is enough for debug purpose, and the code has printed the sensor value at the end of the method (around line 147), so I'm going to just delete this. If you want to keep it for debug purpose, please let me know, thanks.
Here
This is looking pretty good to me.  Could you find someone from your team to review it to make sure it does what it needs to?
BTW, new 1800 lines added and not a single test case... we probably should get some amount of test case coverage here, right?
Sure, I'll design some test cases.

Hi, Patrick, I've modified some code based on the suggestions, but I encountered some side effects during my regression test: the executable file "sensor-monitor" was not installed to /usr/bin.

The root cause is that we've modified the target of pkg_postinst() from sensor-monitor to ${PN}-sensor-monitor (Link: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/60040), but the install command in phosphor-fan_git.bb still targets to sensor-monitor, I'll push a fix to openbmc's repo, and update my new patchset into this change ASAP.
Any reason this isn't 'const'?
nit: I think _ is often used for a structured-binding name that is unused to make it more obvious.

Sure, I'll follow it. Just a mention, I originally prefer _ is used for private members to highlight data members (after my survey, I think it's no longer needed), I wonder know if there is a standard claims the style you said or it is just a convention, could you kindly provide some information so that I can do some research?

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#naming-conventions

> We generally abstain from any prefix or suffix on names.
Done, there is no data would be updated, 'const' is added.

The only time we're using alarmInterface and alarmProperties is here.  Why keep them as two different maps?  We've doubled the lookup time.  We could use a light-weight struct and/or tuple to store both of these in one map and cut the amount of lookup work in half.
Ack. There are some data structures are moved from the original implementation, I'll design an more effective way to search them.
ideally we'd use lg2 on a new file like this.
Sure, I'll refactor to lg2.

const& or const&&

It isn't obvious why we need the heavy weight of a map here when we seem to always create this with one entry on line 64.

In these 2 scenarios, AlarmChecker.checkAlarm() will be called:

1. When any host is powered on, ShutdownAlarmMonitor will check all alarms.
   - ShutdownAlarmMonitor --> AlarmChecker --> AlarmHandler

2. When a watched alarm property is changed. (propertiesChanged() in DbusAlarmMonitor)
   - DbusAlarmMonitor --> AlarmChecker --> AlarmHandler

The map "properties" is created by sdbusplus::message_t's member
```
void DbusAlarmMonitor::propertiesChanged(sdbusplus::message_t& message)
{
    std::map<std::string, std::variant<bool>> properties;
    std::string interface;

    message.read(interface, properties);
    .
    .
    .
```

In (2), since DbusAlarmMonitor should not know what alarm property to read (SRP: It should only watches dbus alarms), I pass the whole map down to AlarmHanlder.

Responsibility of each classes:
- DbusAlarmMonitor: Watch/Stop watching Dbus alarms.
- AlarmChecker: Distribute which AlarmHandler should handle the alarm.
- AlarmHandler: Handle specific alarm changing.

Line 64 belongs to (1), since "Host is powered on" is the trigger instead of alarm changing, the property need to be queried manually, to unify the interface of checkAlarm(), It create the same map and insert the value.

Why shared_ptr?  Isn't unique_ptr sufficient here?

It isn't obvious why we're even bothering with dynamic memory here.  Couldn't checkAlarm pass in the sensorPath + properties and we call the instance directly?

Ack. unique_ptr is sufficient here, thanks for reminding.

Since it is not possible to return a refernce to a temporary object on the stack, in my knowledge, I have three options:

(1) Return it by value
(2) Return by reference via a pointer.
(3) Return by reference what you received by reference as an argument.

For (1), there might be unecessary copy operation, depends on compiler's algorithm, and I think (3) is too C-like. I chose std::shared_ptr (2) as a result, it will be great for disscussion if you have another option.

Considering that `obtainAlarmHandler(...)->checkAlarm(...)` is only called on line 75/76, I don't think we really need an instance passed back.  Instead of having this function do a type -> AlarmHandler conversion, have it take a (type, path) and call the AlarmHandler directly.
Sure, I think it is better, working on it.

nit: You may want:

```
AlarmChecker() = delete;
```
Done

I'm not especially keen on this passing all the way down here as a reference.  Isn't this constructed from some JSON at some point?  Seems like we're asking for trouble to keep it as a reference.

I'd suggest the constructor take an r-value reference that we std::move into the class property, unless you have a strong reason for passing it (and storing it) as a reference into this class.  I think this behavior should be clearly documented in the constructor parameter.
nit: any idea why this is prefixed with underscore?  Generally we don't use prefix/suffix like this.
Done, removed.
I think you should split this into two files (at least).  One for "ProtectionAlarmHandler" behavior and one for "RecoveryAlarmHandler" behavior.
Why are we using this header?  I don't see any RTTI being used here.
Done
Please define these in phosphor-dbus-interfaces.
Why do we have an error for clear?  Shouldn't this be a Resolved setting on the existing log?  An alarm clearing isn't an error.
We still need informational event logs for the clear.

Is that existing behavior?  It seems odd to me to have an event for the disappearance of an error condition.  Isn't that the sort of thing that the "Resolved" field is for?

I guess this was copy/pasted from shutdown_alarm_monitor.
yea, it's existing behavior.
Prefer use of sdbusplus::client::xyz::openbmc_project::logging::Create::interface and sdbusplus::client::xyz::openbmc_project::sensor::Value::interface constants.
Move below at least line 87.  None of these are used prior to that.  You don't need to forward declare variables like in C.
Use lg2 throughout.
nit: spelling
Done

I'm 98% sure `system_clock` is not what you want here.  I suspect you want `steady_clock`?

`system_clock` is subject to adjustments based on NTP, leap seconds, etc.

It appears that shutdown_alarm_monitor.cpp is also using `system_clock` and you likely copy/pasted that code here.  It should also be fixed (in a separate commit).
Since it is existing behavior, I actually don't know the reason of taking use of ```system_clock```, @Matt could you kindly explain for us?
that's a mistake on my part

Please do not create a singleton type like this.  There are already other uses of this type for other purposes (the shutdown_alarm_monitor).  Find somewhere to put the instance at associated specifically to what you're trying to accomplish here.  Maybe it belongs in the AlarmChecker?

This is really irritating that AlarmTimestamps uses a uint64_t instead of a std::chrono type.  I have no idea without digging into other uses what time units they intend to store.  Can we refactor this?

It looks like shutdown_alarm_monitor.hpp uses milliseconds so at least you are consistent.

The ProtectionAlarmHandler is actually refactored from shutdown_alarm_monitor's checkAlarm() and startTimer(), it performs exactly the same behavior as the original functions, so the access of AlarmTimestamps is for the same purpose.

When any AlarmKey is manipulated at runtime (created, deleted, etc.), the code needs to record it into AlarmTimestamps, it was not a singleton type because the original shoutdown_alarm_monitor acts like a god class, it manages everything like monitor dbus's interface, check the alarms and handle it. It just need to call the same instance at any place since AlarmTimestamps is its private member.

Now I split the behavior of checkAlarm() into ProtectionAlarmHandler, for the purpose of refactoring, I want to make sure that it acts like before, to let different classes be able to access the same instance of AlarmTimestamps, I have two choices:

1. Make the AlarmTimestamps into a singleton type.
2. Pass the instance of AlarmTimestamps around.

I finally chose (1) because I personally don't want to pass this kind of record-type objects around, since that is not a necessary part for the classes to work.

If the options above are still not good enough, I think I have option (3)

3. Bring the conecpt of DomainEvent into AlarmTimestamps, that is, create a new DomainEventSubscriber which stores the instance of AlarmTimestamps, if any object want to record a timestamp, it only needs to publish a DomainEvent, the new subscriber will catch and record it.
I'd prefer (3) over a singleton.  Define some class which holds the state associated with alarm handling, including the timestamp-tracker, and pass that down to subscribers as necessary.

Why is this a reference?  This makes me think something fishy is going on here.


`auto original = previousStartTime->second` appears sufficient?
Done, it is copy/pasted from shutdown_alarm_monitor, ```auto``` is sufficient here.
Don't use `const` for POD function parameters.
Done
nit: `auto`.  At a minimum the `const` here is extra noise.
Done
`else if` ?
Done

It isn't obvious what dynamic inheritance is doing for you.  It seems like you've added this just because the `obtainAlarmHandler` function returns an instance and you want some common sub-type, but I don't really see a need for that.

This seems like a whole lot of object-oriented complexity to effectively create 2 function pointers in `obtainAlarmHandler` ... are you anticipating a lot more of these types in the future?

> The ProtectionAlarmHandler is actually refactored from shutdown_alarm_monitor's checkAlarm() and startTimer(), it performs exactly the same behavior as the original functions...

AlarmHandler's responsiblity is handling some alarms on Dbus, the ProtectionAlarmHandler handles HardShutdown/SoftShutdown, the RecoveryAlarmHandler handles SystemRecovery, if there are any other alarm need to be handle, such as triggering power capping when CPU throttle, over current protection, it can be easily extend to support a new handler.
I've seen this same type passed around way too many times now.  Create a `using` alias for this.

Please don't add a singleton in the class itself.  Find the domain where you are trying to use this and place it there.  Otherwise, as this code is maintained you're going to end up with different uses for different purposes unknowingly colliding with each other.

Sure, I'll adopt option (3) that we discussed above.

> Bring the conecpt of DomainEvent into AlarmTimestamps, that is, create a new DomainEventSubscriber which stores the instance of AlarmTimestamps, if any object want to record a timestamp, it only needs to publish a DomainEvent, the new subscriber will catch and record it.

the timestamps are that so if a shutdown countdown is in progress and the app/BMC gets reboot, the countdown is resumed.  So anywhere you move that Timestamps class to, the shutdown code needs to be able to get the values.  I'm not sure that would be possible if  it were just another subscriber?

Again, this only needs to be in the Protection stuff, so maybe just make it local there?
Changing the on-disk file format without a cereal struct version change??  This seems broken.
This seems a little strange to have a map above but then 2 specific members for 2 specific types and then use the `at` to get specific type->interface maps.
Please use `sdbusRule::propertiesChangedNamespace`
Use lg2 throughout.

All this extra code seems kind of heavy considering we've only set up the matches in the constructor of our own class.  How likely is this to not be found?  Just make the getAlarmType throw (and crash the program) if the reverse-lookup doesn't work.  This is a critical bug and not worth hiding in a log message that nobody will ever see.
Can you just be explicit?  `alarmInterfaces.at(alarmType)`

explicit

Add delete of default constructor.
Please remove all underscore prefixes on members.
Done
Avoid singletons.

Please don't use RTTI.  You need to refactor the SystemProtectionTriggered and SystemRecoveryTriggered classes to encapsulate their 'handle' behavior in their own classes.  Pushing it into this RecoverySubscriber class is not maintainable and RTTI is generally really bad performing (both in code space and code size).
This should be moved into these classes directly.
Can we generate these as a `map<string, std::vector<AlarmType>` in the `parse` function?  It seems kind of expensive to regenerate this vector on each PropertiesChanged event.
Do we generally just log and continue on bad-json loading?  Feels like we might want this to crash?

Since SENSOR_MONITOR_CONFIG_ROOT_PATH is a #define in config.h, we really could construct the full path as a constexpr path in the header file here.  You can do string concatenation in preprocessor/constexpr expressions.
You don't need explicit closes.  The destructor will close on its own.
Done
explicit
Done
`static constexpr` ?

There seems like a lot of deleted code here.  Is the JSON format exactly the same and this is covered in some of the new places?  Or do we need to warn users that they have to transition over to a new JSON format?
I swear I've seen this map 3-4 times in this commit.  Please put it in a single place.
Since there are a number of unresolved comments I'm going to assume this is still a WIP.
